pr_title: GEODE-8672: No need in token mode if concurrencyChecksEnabled

timeline.message:
GEODE-8672: No need in token mode if concurrencyChecksEnabled

  * The DESTROYED token is only needed to prevent concurrent destroy op
    is lost in GII. If concurrency checks are enabled, the version tag
    should be able to prevent the destroy op being lost.

timeline.bodyText: This method might be better named "isInTokenModeNeeded." This will also require that test names in LocalRegionTest be changed.
timeline.author: DonalEvans

timeline.bodyText:
This test name seems not to match with what the test is doing. The call to isNeedInTokenMode() has needTokensForGII as true and needRIDestroyToken as false, but the name seems to imply that needRIDestroyToken is true.
Also, would it be worth adding a test for the case where needTokensForGII is false and needRIDestroyToken is true, for completeness?
timeline.author: DonalEvans

replies.bodyText: Actually both setting is used to determine if Destroyed token is needed. But you are right, it is a little confusing. I have changed the test name and added another test case.
replies.author: pivotal-eshu

timeline.bodyText: Can this not be a ConcurrentLinkedQueue or possibly use Collections.synchronizedList()?
timeline.author: kohlmu-pivotal

timeline.bodyText: This synchronization block should be replaced with a collection that handles concurrency, like ConcurrencyLinkedQueue or Collections.synchronizedList()
timeline.author: kohlmu-pivotal

timeline.bodyText: All of this can be replaced with an ExecutorService
timeline.author: kohlmu-pivotal

replies.bodyText: Can ExecutorService be used in a server vm? I tried using the ExecutorService but was failed as the rule not applied in a server vm.
replies.author: pivotal-eshu

replies.bodyText: Never heard of a reason why it should not be able to.
replies.author: kohlmu-pivotal

timeline.bodyText: All of this can be replaced with an ExecutorService
timeline.author: kohlmu-pivotal

timeline.bodyText: Can this not be a ConcurrentLinkedQueue or possibly use Collections.synchronizedList()?
timeline.author: kohlmu-pivotal

timeline.bodyText: Small change, but can you swap the check around? First evaluate the ConcurrencyCheck. As this check has a greater chance to short circuit the conditional sooner.
timeline.author: kohlmu-pivotal

timeline.bodyText:
I was more thinking in the line of using the invokeAll rather than the single submit. With invokeAll you can create all the operations up front and then invoke all of them at the same time.
Are we not concerned that if we do it this way, that there is a possibility that the concurrency issue is possibly not ever hit?
timeline.author: kohlmu-pivotal
